conversation.content: [shaky voice] Emma, it's really you standing here weighing apples in this grocery store after all these years. [pause] I've had investigators searching three states, and here you were twenty minutes from the estate.
The name's Alex now, and I need you to step back from my station before my manager notices. These organic honeycrisps need to be sorted by four o'clock.
[desperately] You just disappeared that night after the argument about the development project. [very quietly] Your mother cried herself to sleep for months, wondering if you were even alive.
[bitter] She cried about losing her heir, not her child. [coldly] Both of you only ever saw me as an extension of your land empire, another asset to manage and develop.
[pleading] That's not true, we wanted you to have everything we never had growing up. [sighs] The properties, the education, the connections—it was all supposed to be yours someday.

[monotone] I stack produce for eight dollars an hour, share a studio apartment with two roommates, and eat the bruised fruit nobody else wants. [firmly] This life is more honest than anything you offered.
[quietly] I've kept your room exactly as you left it, even that ridiculous band poster you loved. [pause] The trust fund still has your name on it, untouched, accumulating interest.
Money from displacing families, from turning farmland into strip malls, from choosing profit over people every single time. [exhales] I'd rather earn minimum wage than touch those accounts.
[defeated] Your grandfather built that company from nothing, worked himself into an early grave establishing something to pass down. [very quietly] Now I'm seventy-three with no one to leave it to.
Maybe you should have thought about that before bulldozing the Martinez family orchards where three generations lived. They shop here now, can barely afford groceries.
[whispering] I know I made mistakes, terrible choices that hurt people. [clearing throat] But losing you was the only consequence that actually taught me anything about what matters.
[exhausted] It's been six years, Dad. [sighs] Six years of building a life without your shadow, without feeling guilty for not wanting to be you.
[anxious] Just have dinner with us, one meal, let your mother see you're okay. [quickly] After that, if you want us to leave you alone forever, we will.
She sent you here alone, didn't she? Too proud to walk into a grocery store herself, too afraid I'd reject her in public.
[very meekly] She's in the car outside, has been for two hours working up the courage. [pause] Diabetes took most of her eyesight last year, but she insisted on coming anyway.
[very quietly] She's blind now? [long pause] Nobody told me, I didn't know she was sick, I would have—no, it doesn't change anything.
[gently] It changes that she can't see the disappointment in your eyes anymore. [sighs] Maybe that's the only reason she's brave enough to try this.
[shaky voice] My shift ends at five-thirty, and there's a diner two blocks north that serves her favorite pie. [very quietly] One hour, that's all you get.
[relieved] One hour is more than I dared hope for after all this time. [warmly] Thank you, Emma—I mean Alex, thank you for giving us even that.
[firmly] One hour. [pause] That's it.

scenario: A wealthy land baron discovers their estranged child working as a produce clerk at a grocery store after years of searching.
